Flags so feature flags are a technique basically that are is not it's not new

another customer of ours uh really loves feature Flags they can cut releases down and really scope them down so they can

wrong in the field uh the old days was that you would scramble and do a roll back or a patch
um this is a style of software that I grew up and it was always agonizing uh because when you have a bug out in the
world and you're trying to do uh a patch you get really hurried and your brain
starts to to to pump out chemicals that sometimes make you have really bad decisions uh so when I was at vignette I
was an engineering release manager and we once shipped a surface pack that had a really bad bug and we
had had levels of severity of bugs of like cosmetic defect this was the absolute worst bug
which was that it went in and deleted all their customers content on an upgrade when your customers are
newspapers and you delete all their content and an upgrade they get pretty unhappy with you very quickly um so this
was a bug that we need to fix immediately when we went to fix it we kind of trampled on some other stuff and
we did a fix pack a and then realized we broke it something else we went up to F in about 4 hours before we got to a
semi-stable point all because we were just kind of in this hurry and kept making mistakes so the really nice thing
about feature Flags is that you can turn off a feature in the field and fix all these mistakes kind of at your leisure
um so you can have a meantime to remediate where the the bug is not visible anymore but instead you could kind of calmly uh and not in a panic
figure out what's going wrong um a lot of our uh customers also really like this
because usually when a bug happens the person I don't I I don't know if this is Harbaugh's law but if a bug happens the
person with the most knowledge is usually in some remote island you know sipping sipping a beer without
Wi-Fi uh I I don't know why this is you know because bugs always happen in software but generally it's like well oh
my gosh you know Susan would know exactly what to do she doesn't have
Wi-Fi uh so the really nice thing about a feature flag is that if a bug does happen you can just turn turn it off and
you can wait till Monday or when the people who you know uh who know what to do are back to the office and then you can work on it so feature flags are
great uh it avoids a messy roll back and it also allows you to stop bugs well not
they always be bugs it allows you to stop the effects of bugs while you fix what's happening all right so launch
sharly is a feature management platform we have a thousand plus customers worldwide um I am not going to talk

about some good patterns I've seen and some bad patterns I've seen and I hope everybody walks away with something a
question for me or something they learned all right so I already talked about uh one of the major benefits of
feature Flags which is just a kill switch uh just if something is going wrong you could just stop it
uh this really reduces a lot of stress when you're not scrambling to do a roll back uh what I've also found is that
there's no such thing as a clean rollback um even if you're trying to be very meticulous with your code base if
you try to say hey we're just going to ship go back to this Branch there's usually like oh but this fix this other defect we can't do that and then you're
in this kind of cherry pick hell so a kill switch is just this really nice thing where you could say okay something
is going wrong let's stop this um we've seen people use these uh
for times of high spikes of traffic uh for example you might have in the US
Black Friday is big if you have an unexpected surge of traffic and something that used to be stable is now not stable you can shut it off uh We've
also had banking customers use this uh I heard a really great story from a banking customer where they had a a
backend API where you could check your digital wallet and this used to be hidden like five screens back in their
mobile app uh where they said basically two people a year seem to actually find it uh they did a a rework of their
mobile app and they moved this digital wallet up to the homepage and suddenly they had about 20,000 people hitting in
an hour and completely flooding this backend API which actually connected they said to Mainframe not set up for
this sort of traffic so with the kill switch instead of having to pull down the entire app what they just did is
killed access to this one feature and then they could uh re uh rearchitecturing
so kill switches are really nice for unexpected events uh merge
conflicts so the the style of development when when I started out was very much I'd say Branch based uh you'd
say okay this is our V1 and we're going to work on that for a long time and then at some point in the future we're going
to cut a one one and then service packs and these all were kind of like this idea these were nicely pruned branches
that kind of went on their own way uh that starts to break if you have
a lot of developers working and how it starts to break is that you have a lot of developers who are having all these little branches and then it comes the
time to put them back together and it just does not merge easily uh I have heard horror stories
from people at that they had merge parties um you know where they would just basically have eight hours of
discussion of whose Branch would win this doesn't sound like my idea of a party
um the the other metaphor I've heard for branches is that they're just inventory
and they could become extremely wasteful uh I've heard stories of branches that after 3 weeks of work can never be
merged in because the dependencies uh can no longer be worked out so really
nice thing about feature Flags is that you can move to more of a trunk based development uh the you kids say okay
everything is in master and I'm going to just isolate features and work in them just a trunk uh the push back I usually get
when I mentioned this is people say well that seems like a lot of work you know I really have to think about my cat up front I have to to talk to other people
on my team I have to coordinate with them what packages we're going to use I have to get really crisp about what this

there and my response to that is like all of the stuff you just said about defining functionality up front working

great use case for uh feature flagging um with a controlled roll out you could put a portion of traffic to a new

and by wasting I mean a lot of time being in staging and trying to replicate a bug that could not be

uh we would test sloted staging and we get this bug and we couldn't reproduce it and we would eventually figure out

dub uh don't kill your staging server unless your CTO is really happy about

Flags uh so if you have a flag called default

flipped disabled documents being uploaded and somebody had flipped this
and they didn't have an audit trol I mean they didn't have an audit Trail and they didn't have uh any access level

said well about six months later it got flipped again but we knew where to look you know when we started getting

Flags uh feature Flags can be a lot of technical
